+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 79.3
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The gravity hiccups, sloshing beer over the rim of Jax’s mug. He steadies it with a calloused hand. “Damn station’s falling apart.” I grin, polishing a glass. “Adds ambiance. You’d miss the wobble if they fixed it.” He snorts. “Only thing I’d miss is your terrible jokes.” A swig, then he leans in. “Heard Black Nova ships are sniffing around the belt. Think they’re up to no good?” I shrug. “They’re always up to no good. But we’re too small for them.” “Maybe, but the grav fluctuations have been worse since they arrived. Coincidence?” “Old reactors acting up.” I wave a hand dismissively, but a knot forms in my stomach. “Also heard they’re after a data runner who stole something big,” Jax adds. “Scanning every ship.” “Great. Just what we need.” The door hisses open. A tall figure slips in, tentacled dreads twitching. They slump onto a stool. “Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double.” I pour, slide it over. “Name?” “Ryn.” Their hand shakes as they down half the glass. “Rough day, Ryn?” “You could say that.” They finish the drink, push the glass for a refill. “Running from something?” A glance at Jax, who pretends not to listen. “From someone. Black Nova.” Jax chokes. I freeze, then force casualness. “Serious. What’d you do?” Ryn leans closer. “Stole a data chip. Proof of their slave trade, weapon deals—enough to bring them down.” I glance around; ears perk up. “And you brought it here? Why?” “Thought I could lose them in the belt, get to a contact. They tracked my ship. Barely made it aboard before they blew it.” They pull out a crystalline sliver. “Need to get this to the right people. Need help.” I shake my head. “I’m just a bartender. Can’t—” “You’re Nettle. Nets. I know who you used to be. Red Comet gang. You were a pilot. You got out, but you’ve got skills.” My heart stutters. No one here knows that. “How?” “A friend. Dax. Hiding on Tau Ceti. He said if I ever needed help, find you. You were the best smuggler in the sector.” “Dax? Still alive?” Memories flood. “Barely. He said you’re the only one who ever got away from the Syndicate. You know how to disappear.” I clench my jaw. “He shouldn’t have sent you. That life’s behind me. I can’t help.” Ryn’s eyes plead. “Please. I can pay. If they get this chip back, they’ll cover everything. Tighten their grip on the outer rim. Thousands will suffer. You know what they’re capable of.” I stare, torn. The gravity pulses, bottles clinking. Ryn grabs the bar. Before I can answer, the door hisses open. Three figures in black synth-leather stride in. Ryn pales. “Enforcers,” they whisper. The leader approaches, boots echoing. I force a smile. “What can I get you?” He slaps a holo-projector on the counter. An image of Ryn flickers. “Seen this guy?” I glance at Ryn, turned away but dreads unmistakable. Stall. “Can’t say I have. Lots of faces.” The enforcer’s eyes narrow. “Sure about that, bartender?” I shrug. “Like I said.” He turns to Jax. “You, miner. Seen him?” Jax sips. “Nope. Just drinking.” “Last chance. Where is he?” The enforcer’s voice hardens. I spread my hands. “I told you—” He slams his fist on the bar. “We tracked his bio-signature here. Hand him over, or we start breaking things.” The gravity surges violently. Glasses shatter; patrons shout; the enforcer stumbles. In the chaos, I grab Ryn’s arm and yank them behind the counter. “Storage room, now!” I shove them toward the back. They scramble away. As gravity steadies, the enforcer straightens, fury in his eyes. “Where’d he go?” I blank my face. “Who?” He slams his palm down. “Don’t play games. That fugitive is Syndicate property. Hand him over, or we shut this place down.” “I don’t know what you’re talking about.” He signals his companions. “Search the place. Tear it apart.” They start moving tables. One barks, “Check the back room!” Another heads for the storage door. The leader leans close. “Look, bartender, we know he’s here. Give him up, and we’ll make it worth your while. Credits, protection, anything.” “I don’t need your credits. And I don’t know what you’re talking about.” He snarls. “When we find him—and we will—you’ll regret this.” “Good luck,” I say, pulse racing. He turns away. I catch Jax’s eye, motion him closer. He leans in. “I need a diversion,” I whisper. “Keep them away from the storage room.” Jax nods. “You owe me one.” He stands abruptly, shouting, “Hey, you overgrown thugs! Why don’t you pick on someone your own size?” He smashes a bottle against a table. All eyes turn. The enforcers converge on him. I slip behind the bar, toward the storage room. Ryn huddles behind a crate. “We have to move,” I say. “Now.” The gravity flickers, as if the station itself is holding its breath, waiting for what comes next.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates solid competence in executing the prompt requirements while delivering an engaging sci-fi bar scene. The author successfully establishes the cozy sci-fi atmosphere of The Last Outpost, introduces Nettle as a bartender with a hidden past, and creates meaningful conflict through the arrival of both a data runner and pursuing enforcers. The dialogue feels natural and serves multiple purposes - advancing plot, revealing character backgrounds, and building tension. The conversation between Nets and Jax establishes worldbuilding efficiently, while Ryn's desperate plea reveals both their situation and Nets' concealed identity as a former smuggler. The enforcers' interrogation maintains appropriate menace without becoming cartoonish. Character actions remain believable throughout. Nets' reluctance to help despite her past makes sense, as does Jax's willingness to create a diversion for someone he barely knows - it fits the established camaraderie of the outpost community. Ryn's desperation and the enforcers' methodical approach both ring true to their respective situations. The pacing works well, building from casual bar conversation to immediate danger. The gravity fluctuations serve as both atmospheric detail and convenient plot device, though this borders on being too convenient. The author shows restraint in not resolving the conflict, leaving Nets in a precarious position that promises future complications. However, some elements feel familiar rather than fresh. The "bartender with a secret past" and "data chip containing damning evidence" are well-worn tropes, though they're executed competently. The prose occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly in describing emotions and motivations. The writing maintains consistent tone throughout, balancing the cozy atmosphere with genuine tension. Descriptive elements like "tentacled dreads" and "black synth-leather" efficiently establish the sci-fi setting without overwhelming the narrative. + Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 77.5
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter Two: Welcome to New Orleans** I’m standing on the corner of Bourbon and something, trying not to look as lost as I feel. The bus driver dumped me here an hour ago, said it was the French Quarter. The sun’s just coming up, painting the old buildings in gold, but all I see are shadows. My backpack weighs a ton, and my stomach’s been growling since Tennessee. Twenty-seven dollars in my pocket. Phone battery: twelve percent. No charger. Welcome to New Orleans, Taylor. I wander until I find a convenience store, buy a Coke and a bag of chips. The cashier eyes me like I’m trouble. Maybe I am. I head to Jackson Square, find an empty bench. The place is quiet, just a few early birds and some homeless folks curled up on the grass. I sit, crunch on chips, and try to figure out my next move. My phone buzzes. It’s a text from Mom: *Where are you? Please call.* I stare at it, my chest tight. She didn’t care when I came out, but now she cares? Bullshit. I swipe it away. I open Chrome, type “LGBTQ shelter New Orleans.” The page loads slow. Battery drops to nine percent. I get an address, but it’s miles away. I screenshot it, then power off. Can’t afford to lose my last lifeline. A voice cuts through my thoughts. “You look like you could use a friend.” I glance up. A kid about my age stands a few feet away, lanky, with a faded backpack and a bandana around their wrist. Their hair is dyed blue at the tips. They give a half-smile. “I’m good,” I say, turning away. “Sure you are. Where’d you come from?” “Tennessee.” “Ah, the Volunteer State. I’m from Alabama. Name’s Cameron.” I nod. “Taylor.” Cameron sits on the bench, leaving a respectful distance. “How long you been here?” “About an hour.” Cameron chuckles. “Yeah, you’ve got that fresh-off-the-bus look. You got a place to stay?” I shrug. “Working on it.” “There’s a spot a few blocks from here. Some of us crash there. It’s safe, mostly. You can stay tonight if you want.” I eye them. “Why are you helping me?” “Because someone helped me when I first got here. And… I know what it’s like to have nowhere to go.” Their gaze drops for a second, a shadow crossing their face. “Also, it’s easier to survive with a crew.” I chew my lip. Could be a trap. But Cameron seems genuine, and they’re alone. Maybe they’re just a good person. Or maybe they want something. “You run away?” Cameron asks. “Yeah. Family didn’t accept me.” I leave it vague. My hand touches the small trans flag pin on my backpack strap, a gift from a friend back home. Cameron’s eyes follow the movement. “Cool pin,” they say, pulling aside their own jacket to reveal a similar one pinned to their bag. “They/them?” I nod. “You?” “Same.” Cameron smiles. “So you’re in good company.” That eases some tension. But still, trusting a stranger is risky. My phone buzzes again. I turn it on, against my better judgment. Another text from Mom: *Taylor, this isn’t funny. Come home.* Battery: six percent. I grit my teeth. She never used my name before. It feels like a slap. I power off. Cameron watches me. “Parents?” “Yeah.” “You can call them if you need. I’ve got a charger at the spot.” I shake my head. “No. I’m not going back.” Cameron nods. “I get it.” We sit in silence for a moment. The sun is higher now, and the square is filling with tourists and street performers. I feel invisible among them. “So, what’s the place like?” I ask. “It’s an abandoned warehouse near the river. Not the Ritz, but it’s dry and we keep it clean. There’s about five of us, sometimes more. We look out for each other.” “Sounds okay.” My mind races. Is this a good idea? But what are my alternatives? Wander until my money runs out, then sleep on the street alone? I’ve seen enough movies to know how that ends. “Look,” Cameron says, standing up. “I’m not gonna force you. But if you want to come, now’s the time. I’ve got some stuff to do later.” I hesitate, then stand and hoist my backpack. “Okay. Show me.” Cameron’s grin is bright. “Cool. Follow me.” We start walking, weaving through the crowded streets. I keep my guard up, but Cameron seems relaxed, pointing out landmarks and warning me about which cops to avoid. I try to memorize the route, just in case. My binder digs into my ribs—a constant reminder of why I can’t go back. I adjust my shirt, hoping Cameron doesn’t notice. As we turn down a quieter street, Cameron’s expression turns serious. “There’s something you should know. Some of the others… they’ve got issues. We all do. But we stick together. And we don’t ask too many questions about the past. You cool with that?” I nod, though my heart beats faster. Secrets. I’ve got my own. “Good. Just keep your head down, and you’ll be fine.” We walk in silence for a few minutes. The sun beats down, and I’m sweating. I think about my phone, dead soon. No way to call for help. No way back. I glance at Cameron, who’s scanning the street like they’re looking for something—or someone. Maybe this is a mistake. But it’s the only move I’ve got. We stop in front of a crumbling brick building near the river. Graffiti covers the walls, and a rusted metal door hangs slightly ajar. Cameron pushes it open with a creak. “Home sweet home,” they say. As I step inside, my phone buzzes one last time—a final plea from Mom, I’m sure—and then the screen goes black. Out of battery, out of options. I take a deep breath and follow Cameron into the dark.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates solid competence in young adult fiction writing while maintaining authentic voice and emotional resonance. The author successfully captures Taylor's vulnerable yet defiant mindset through effective first-person narration that feels genuinely teenage without being forced or overly stylized. The adherence to instructions is strong - the piece follows Taylor through their first day in New Orleans, introduces Cameron as another runaway with hints of secrets, incorporates internal monologue effectively, and maintains the requested mixed tense approach. The 1000-word target is met appropriately. Character development shows nuance, particularly in Taylor's conflicted emotions about family contact and their cautious approach to trusting Cameron. The internal struggle between desperation and self-preservation feels authentic. Cameron is sketched efficiently with enough detail to feel real while maintaining mystery about their background and motivations. The dialogue feels natural and age-appropriate, avoiding both overly mature speech and clichéd teen-speak. The conversation flows organically and reveals character while advancing plot. The shared trans identity creates believable connection without feeling contrived. Descriptively, the piece effectively establishes New Orleans setting through selective details - Bourbon Street, Jackson Square, the warehouse location - without overwhelming the narrative. The imagery serves the story rather than dominating it. The emotional complexity is well-handled, showing Taylor's simultaneous relief at escape, fear of the unknown, anger at family rejection, and desperate hope for acceptance. The phone messages from their mother add effective tension and highlight the finality of Taylor's choice. Structurally, the chapter moves purposefully from isolation to tentative connection, building appropriate tension about whether trusting Cameron is wise. The ending creates effective uncertainty about what lies ahead while providing a natural stopping point. Some minor weaknesses include occasional reliance on familiar runaway narrative beats and a few moments where the prose becomes slightly mechanical in conveying information. The piece also doesn't quite achieve the emotional depth that might elevate it from competent to exceptional. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 14 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 17.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 14.0, Elegant Prose: 14.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 70.0
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**My Apocalypse Buddy** The world had ended, but Midas often thought it could have ended more neatly. The rusty bus he called home was proof: it had stalled on the shoulder of the old highway and then become home to generations of rats, spiders, and finally one hapless scavenger and his animatronic koala. Chewy sat on the cracked dashboard, his fur matted but still soft, his eyes a steady blue. Midas was pretty sure blue meant “content,” or possibly “low power.” The manual had been lost, along with most of civilization.* Chewy was a relic of the Before Times, designed to respond to the emotions of his child owner, his eyes changing color like a mood ring with a power supply. Now, in a world where hiding your fear was a matter of life and death, Chewy was about as subtle as a neon sign. “We need batteries, Chewy,” Midas said, scanning his meager list. “And food. And maybe a new wheel for the bus.” Chewy’s eyes flickered yellow. “Don’t look at me like that. I’ve got a plan.” The yellow deepened to orange. “All right, it’s not so much a plan as a direction. We’ll go to the old MegaMart. There’s bound to be something.” Chewy’s eyes flashed red. Midas ignored it. If he listened to Chewy’s warnings, they’d never leave the bus. They set off, Midas with a backpack and a stout stick, Chewy perched on his shoulder like a furry, judgmental parrot. The road was a graveyard of asphalt and ambition, but Midas knew the way. Or thought he did. Midas had a knack for trouble. If there was a single landmine in a field, he would find it. If there was a bandit behind a tree, he would trip over him. If there was a banana peel in a post-apocalyptic wasteland, Midas would slip on it. Chewy’s eyes had seen it all, and they rarely approved. The first obstacle was the remains of Highway 42, where a collapsed overpass left only a narrow beam spanning a ravine. Midas edged onto it, trying not to look down. Chewy’s eyes began to pulse a soft red. “It’s fine, Chewy,” Midas muttered. “Just a little balancing act.” The beam creaked. Chewy’s red brightened. Below, a group of bandits camping in the ravine looked up, drawn by the flashing. “Hey! Who’s up there?” one shouted. Midas froze. Chewy’s eyes went crimson. The bandits scrambled toward the beam. Midas hurried forward, the beam swaying alarmingly. He reached the far side just as the first bandit set foot on it. The beam gave way with a groan, sending the bandits into the ravine amid a symphony of clangs and curses that would have made a composer weep. Midas allowed himself a smile. Chewy’s eyes shifted to a dubious yellow. “That could have been worse,” Midas said. The rest of the journey was punctuated by minor calamities: a swarm of bees that took offense to Midas’s hat, a patch of suspiciously sticky mud that tried to claim his boots, and a sign that read “Danger: Landmines” which Midas was fairly sure was just a prank. (He still gave it a wide berth.) At last, the MegaMart loomed, its windows long gone, its sign dangling by a single bolt. Inside, it was a cathedral of emptiness. Midas lit a torch and began to search. They wandered through aisles labeled “Electronics,” “Home & Garden,” and “Toys,” finding only dust and disappointment. Then, in the camping section, Midas spotted a pack of batteries. “Jackpot!” he exclaimed. Chewy’s eyes flashed green. Midas snatched the batteries and shoved them into his pack. At that moment, a voice echoed through the cavernous space: “Drop the goods, friend.” Midas turned to see One-Eyed Pete, leader of the local scavenger gang, aiming a crossbow. “We don’t want trouble,” Midas said, trying to sound calm. Chewy’s eyes, however, turned a telltale red. One-Eyed Pete grinned. “Your bear says otherwise. Hand over the pack.” Midas considered his options. Run? The crossbow made that risky. Fight? He had a stick. Negotiate? Chewy’s eyes were now flickering between red and green like a malfunctioning traffic light. The bizarre display seemed to distract Pete. “What’s wrong with your bear?” he asked, lowering the crossbow a fraction. Seizing the moment, Midas bolted. He grabbed Chewy and dashed down the aisle, knocking over a tower of canned beans to slow pursuit. They burst out the back door into the parking lot, where Pete’s gang was already giving chase. Midas spotted an abandoned shopping cart. He tossed Chewy into it and began pushing. The cart gained speed down the slope, but one wheel was wonky, causing it to veer wildly. They careened past dumpsters, around potholes, and finally crashed into a stack of pallets, sending both Midas and Chewy flying. Midas scooped up Chewy and ran toward the stream that wound through the ruins. They plunged in and let the current carry them, hoping to lose their pursuers. When they finally dragged themselves onto the bank, they were miles from home, soaked, and minus the backpack (it had been swept away). The stream had carried them past several landmarks, including the half-sunken statue of a politician nobody remembered, and the rusted hulk of a food truck that still smelled vaguely of tacos. Midas’s stomach growled, but the backpack—and its precious can of beans—was gone. Chewy’s eyes were a steady blue, which Midas interpreted as resigned acceptance. They walked the rest of the way, limping, their clothes torn. As they approached the bus, the sun was setting, casting a golden glow over the rusted hull. Midas opened the door and collapsed onto the floor. Chewy’s eyes flickered a weak yellow. “Well,” Midas said, “we didn’t get the batteries, but we got an adventure.” Chewy’s eyes dimmed to a soft green, then went out. Midas sighed. “I’ll find some batteries tomorrow. Promise.” He placed Chewy on the shelf and lay down, exhausted. In the darkness, Chewy’s eyes briefly glowed red, then went dark again. --- *The manual had been lost, but even if it had survived, it would have been in Japanese, and Midas didn’t speak a word. Besides, the apocalypse had rendered most warranties void.*
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This story successfully captures many elements of Terry Pratchett's distinctive style, particularly his dry wit, footnoted asides, and ability to find humor in dire circumstances. The premise of a hapless survivor paired with a mood-ring animatronic koala is genuinely creative and provides a solid foundation for both comedy and pathos. The narrative structure follows the prompt requirements well, beginning with deliberation, moving through a mission that goes sideways, and returning home worse for wear. The author demonstrates good understanding of pacing and maintains consistent momentum throughout the adventure. The characterization of Midas as perpetually unlucky works effectively, and Chewy's color-changing eyes serve as both a clever narrative device and source of humor. The relationship between them feels authentic despite Chewy's mechanical nature. The author shows restraint in not over-explaining their bond, letting it develop naturally through their interactions. The prose generally flows well and captures Pratchett's observational humor, particularly in lines like "The world had ended, but Midas often thought it could have ended more neatly." The footnote about the manual being in Japanese is a nice Pratchett-esque touch. However, the story suffers from some structural weaknesses. The sequence of obstacles feels somewhat episodic rather than building toward a cohesive climax. The encounter with One-Eyed Pete, while entertaining, resolves too easily and doesn't feel particularly consequential. The shopping cart escape sequence, while amusing, strains credibility even within the story's established tone. The ending feels appropriately bittersweet for the genre, with their failure tempered by survival and companionship. The final image of Chewy's eyes briefly glowing red adds a nice touch of ambiguity. The dialogue, while limited, serves its purpose adequately, though it could be more distinctive. The descriptive passages effectively establish the post-apocalyptic setting without becoming overwrought. Overall, this is a competent piece that successfully emulates its target style while telling an engaging story, though it lacks the deeper philosophical undercurrents that made Pratchett's work truly exceptional. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 13 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 12 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 8 Weak Dialogue: 10 Tell-Don't-Show: 9 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 8 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 17.0, Believable Character Actions: 14.0, Nuanced Characters: 13.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15.0, Elegant Prose: 14.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 12.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 8.0, Weak Dialogue: 10.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 9.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 8.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 67.0
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell above Chapter One Books jingled as Oliver Thorne slipped inside, glancing over his shoulder. Outside, a drizzle cast a grey sheen over Cardiff's Castle Arcade. Oliver removed his sunglasses, scanning the cozy interior. Behind the counter, Gwen Thomas looked up from her paperback, one eyebrow raised. "Afternoon," Oliver said, flashing his trademark smile. "Lovely little shop." "Thank you," Gwen replied, returning to her book. Oliver blinked. He wandered, trailing a finger along the spines. "Do you have any signed first editions? Dylan Thomas, perhaps? I'm a collector." Gwen didn't look up. "We have first editions, but not signed. The signed ones are in that case—not for sale." "Why keep them if not to sell?" Oliver asked, moving closer. "Because I like them," Gwen said simply. Oliver chuckled. "Fair enough." He leaned against the counter. "Not much of a talker, are you?" "I talk when there's something to say." "Could you recommend a book? Something I might enjoy." Gwen marked her page and set the book down. She gave him a once-over. "What do you like? Thrillers? Romance? Biography?" "Surprise me." Gwen slid off her stool, walked to a shelf, and handed him a volume. "This one's about an actor who thinks he's god's gift. A comedy." Oliver raised an eyebrow. "You think I'm an actor?" "Oliver Thorne, right? I've seen your face on billboards." "Ah. And here I thought I was incognito." "The sunglasses and hat might work if you weren't so... noticeable." "Noticeable? I'll take that as a compliment." "Take it as you like." "You're not impressed by celebrities, I gather." "Should I be?" "Most people are. Refreshing to meet someone who isn't." "I'm sure you meet many refreshing people." Oliver laughed. "Actually, no. It's mostly sycophants. I ducked in to escape paparazzi." Gwen's expression softened a fraction. "You're welcome to browse. Just don't disturb the books." "I wouldn't dream of it." He moved away, browsing. Gwen watched him. He was more handsome in person; she felt a flutter but steeled herself. After a few minutes, Oliver returned. "So, Gwen—" he read her name tag. "Yes?" "How long have you owned this shop?" "Five years." "You must love books." "I do." "Me too. My favorite is 'The Count of Monte Cristo'." "Really? Most people say that to sound well-read." Oliver grinned. "Guilty. Actually, I love 'The Princess Bride'." "That's a good one." "Have you read it?" "Yes. I liked the movie too." "I'm more of a book person. Though I make movies." "Obviously." A comfortable silence fell. Oliver leaned on the counter, closing the distance. "You're quite intriguing, Gwen." "And you're quite forward, Mr. Thorne." "Call me Oliver. Please." "Oliver. Would you like to buy a book?" "Maybe. But I'd rather buy you coffee. When do you close?" "At six." "After six, then." "I have plans." "Tomorrow?" "I'm busy." Oliver feigned a wounded look. "You're breaking my heart. I'm not used to rejection." "I'm sure you'll survive." Oliver sighed, then noticed movement outside. A photographer was peering in. "Damn, they found me." Gwen followed his gaze. Without thinking, she grabbed his arm and pulled him behind the counter. They crouched together, knees touching. Gwen's heart pounded; Oliver's eyes widened, then crinkled with amusement. "Stay down," Gwen whispered. "He'll go away." "Thank you," Oliver whispered back. "You're my hero." Gwen rolled her eyes but smiled. They waited, rain pattering against the window. After a minute, Gwen peeked over the counter. The photographer was gone. She stood, Oliver rising with her, his hand on her waist to steady himself. Gwen stepped back quickly, blushing. "That was exciting," Oliver said. "Like a spy novel." "Just another day in Cardiff," Gwen replied, hoping her voice was steady. Oliver brushed a strand of hair from his face. "Let me take you to dinner as a thank you." "That's not necessary." "I insist. Besides, I'd like to get to know you better. You're not like anyone I've met in a long time." Gwen hesitated, charmed despite herself. "I don't date customers." "I'm not a customer yet." He grabbed a book. "I'll buy this. Now I am. So dinner's off?" Gwen laughed. "That's not how it works." "What would convince you?" She searched his eyes. "Why are you so interested? You just met me." Oliver ran a hand through his hair, his bravado slipping. "Because you see me—not the celebrity. You treat me like a normal person; it's refreshing. And you're smart, beautiful, and funny. I'd be a fool not to be interested." Gwen felt her cheeks warm. "That's a nice speech. But you don't know me." "Hence the dinner." Gwen took a deep breath. "Alright. One dinner. Not tonight though; I need to prepare." Oliver's face lit up. "Tomorrow at seven?" "Okay. But I'm not promising anything." "That's all I ask." He handed her the book—a copy of *How to Win Friends and Influence People*—and paid. As he turned to leave, he paused. "Until tomorrow, Gwen." She watched him leave, heart racing. She touched her flushed cheek. She couldn't believe she'd agreed, but part of her already looked forward to it.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates solid competence in executing the prompt's requirements while falling short of exceptional creative writing. The author successfully establishes the Welsh setting (Cardiff's Castle Arcade), creates the meet-cute scenario with paparazzi pursuit, and develops the requested character dynamics through predominantly dialogue-driven narrative. The characterization shows promise but lacks depth. Oliver exhibits the required roguish charm and fragile ego, particularly evident when he admits to lying about his favorite book and shows genuine vulnerability when his usual tactics fail. However, his character feels somewhat surface-level, relying on familiar celebrity tropes. Gwen's immunity to his charm is well-established, and her internal conflict between resistance and attraction is present but could be more nuanced. The dialogue carries the scene effectively, with distinct voices for each character. Gwen's terse, practical responses contrast nicely with Oliver's more elaborate, performative speech patterns. The banter feels natural, particularly the exchange about signed books and the Princess Bride revelation. However, some moments feel predictable, such as the "you're breaking my heart" line. The hiding-behind-the-counter sequence provides good physical tension and serves as an effective catalyst for their connection. The author handles the shift from verbal sparring to physical proximity well, showing rather than telling the growing attraction. Structurally, the piece flows logically from initial meeting through escalating attraction to the dinner agreement. The pacing works, though some transitions feel slightly abrupt. The ending, while positive, doesn't feel entirely unearned given the groundwork laid throughout the scene. The prose is clean and functional but lacks distinctive voice or memorable imagery. Descriptions are minimal but adequate for the dialogue-heavy format requested. The writing avoids purple prose but also doesn't achieve particular elegance. The piece succeeds as competent genre fiction that fulfills its brief but doesn't transcend into memorable literature. It reads like professional but unremarkable romance writing—technically sound but lacking the spark that would make it truly engaging. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 16 Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 12 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 11 Elegant Prose: 12 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Emotionally Complex: 11 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 8 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6 Unearned Transformations: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 12 Overall Impression: 13
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 16.0, Believable Character Actions: 14.0, Nuanced Characters: 12.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 11.0, Elegant Prose: 12.0, Emotionally Engaging: 13.0, Emotionally Complex: 11.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 6.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12.0, Amateurish: 8.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6.0, Unearned Transformations: 7.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 12.0, Overall Impression: 13.0
+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 60.2
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The heavy iron door groaned open, revealing the underhold's inner sanctum. Flickering gas lamps cast long shadows across the stone floor, their hiss the only sound. In the centre, atop a tarnished brass pedestal, rested the ancient Scythan artifact: an obsidian and gold dagger said to command shadows. Aya's senses prickled. "It's too quiet," she whispered to Katra and Simeon. "Where are the guards?" Simeon's hand tightened on his pistol, brass knuckles gleaming. Katra adjusted her mask, scanning the gloom. "Perhaps the raid caused more chaos than we thought," she offered without conviction. They stepped inside; the door creaked shut with ominous finality. Aya reached for the immateria, that dark well of power inherited from her mother, but hesitated. Using it might trigger alarms. With a sudden hiss, the gas jets flared, banishing shadows and revealing armed figures emerging from behind pillars. At their head stood the Guildmaster herself, whom Aya had last seen being dragged away by the City Watch. "Welcome, my dear traitors," the Guildmaster purred. "You thought me behind bars? The raid was my own design—a test to weed out the disloyal. And you have failed spectacularly." Aya's blood turned to ice. The Guildmaster should have been in a cell, not here with a half-dozen bodyguards training weapons on them. Her brass-and-steel prosthetic arm gleamed, cradling an ornate revolver. Her sharp features twisted into a humorless smile. "Drop your weapons," she commanded, "unless you wish to die where you stand." Simeon let his pistol clatter to the floor; Katra followed suit, lockpicks spilling. Aya raised her hands slowly, mind racing. The Guildmaster stepped forward, boots clicking, and used her revolver barrel to lift Aya's mask. With a flick, she tore it away, revealing aristocratic features. The Guildmaster's eyebrows rose. "I don't recognize you. Who are you?" "Aya Blackwood," she said, forcing steadiness. "Lady Aya of House Blackwood." A murmur rippled through the guards. The Guildmaster's smile widened. "A noble? How delightful. So the high and mighty dabble in our dirty work. And to think you aimed to take my place." Aya lifted her chin. "You're making a mistake. I am worth far more to you alive than dead." The Guildmaster laughed harshly. "Is that so? You think your family would pay ransom for a traitorous witch? I've heard the rumours—you've been using forbidden magicks. Your own mother swung for it. Why should I spare you?" Aya's chest tightened at the mention of her mother. "Because I can offer you protection. My family has influence; the City Watch turns a blind eye to our enterprises. With my support, you could operate with impunity." "Impunity?" The Guildmaster's expression darkened. "You overestimate your worth, girl. You're a disgrace to your house. They'd sooner see you dead than help you." The words struck like a dagger. Aya knew there was truth—her father had disowned her after her mother's execution. Yet she pressed on. "Then consider my other talents. I can summon entities from the immateria. I can be of use. Together we could unlock the artifact's secrets." At the mention of magic, the guards shifted uneasily. The Guildmaster's lip curled. "Magicka is a curse. It brings naught but ruin. I want no part of it." Aya's heart hammered. "Then let me go, and I will disappear. You'll never hear from me again." The Guildmaster's revolver rose, aiming between Aya's eyes. "You know too much. You've seen the underhold, the artifact. No, you must die, all of you." Aya's vision narrowed. She thought of her mother on the gallows, the immateria whispering. "If you kill me, my family will hunt you down. They have connections. They will root out this guild and destroy it." "They would need to find us first," the Guildmaster scoffed. "And by then, we'll be gone. You think I fear your name? This is Morska. The thieves rule the shadows. Your kind stay in their mansions." Aya closed her eyes, bracing for the shot. She felt the immateria stir. Could she summon something before the bullet struck? Too late; the Guildmaster's finger tightened. "Wait!" Katra cried. "She's telling the truth. Her father is Lord Blackwood, the High Magistrate. If she dies, he'll unleash the Inquisition. You know what that means—they'll burn everything." The Guildmaster hesitated, the revolver wavering. Simeon added gruffly, "And they have steamhounds that can track you. You won't escape." Silence hung, broken only by the hiss of gas lamps. The Guildmaster's eyes flicked between her captives, weighing the risks. Finally, she lowered the weapon. "Perhaps you're right. But I cannot let you go free. You'll be my prisoners until I decide what to do with you." She nodded to the guards. "Take them to the cells. And gag the witch—I won't have her chanting curses." Hands seized Aya, binding her wrists with brass cuffs inscribed with runes—crude attempts to dampen the immateria. A filthy rag was shoved into her mouth. As she was dragged away, she caught the Guildmaster's cold gaze. "Welcome to the consequences of your ambition, Lady Blackwood." The underhold's heavy door slammed shut, plunging them into a dim corridor. Aya's mind churned with fear and shame. Her secret was out; her double life was over. Yet, as the guards marched them deeper, a spark of defiance kindled. She was her mother's daughter, after all. And the immateria was not so easily silenced.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates solid competence in following the prompt's requirements while delivering a tense confrontation scene. The author successfully incorporates all the requested story beats: the trio's entry into the underhold, the surprise revelation of the guild leader's presence, Aya's unmasking and capture, and her attempts at negotiation. The Victorian-gothic aesthetic is reasonably well-established through details like gas lamps, brass fittings, and the general atmosphere of industrial grimness. The dialogue serves its functional purpose, with the Guildmaster's voice carrying appropriate menace and Aya's desperation coming through in her increasingly frantic bargaining attempts. The revelation that the raid was orchestrated by the Guildmaster herself provides a satisfying twist that recontextualizes the opening situation. The world-building elements—the immateria magic system, the brass cuffs with runes, references to steamhounds and the Inquisition—create a coherent fantasy-steampunk hybrid setting. However, the execution suffers from several notable weaknesses. The prose tends toward the workmanlike rather than elegant, with many sentences feeling mechanical and lacking in rhythm. Descriptions often rely on basic sensory details without achieving the atmospheric richness that gothic horror demands. The characterization, while functional, lacks depth—the Guildmaster reads as a fairly standard villain, and Aya's internal conflict about her aristocratic background versus her criminal activities could be explored with greater psychological complexity. The dialogue, while serviceable, occasionally feels stilted and doesn't fully capture the authentic Victorian voice requested in the prompt. Phrases like "my dear traitors" and "how delightful" gesture toward period speech but don't achieve genuine authenticity. The emotional stakes, while present, don't reach the level of intensity that would make this scene truly gripping. The ending, with Aya's spark of defiance, feels somewhat predictable rather than surprising. The piece also struggles with pacing—some moments feel rushed while others drag slightly. The transition from confident infiltration to complete capture happens very quickly, and the negotiation sequence could benefit from more psychological tension and complexity. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 11 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 13 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 12 Elegant Prose: 10 Emotionally Engaging: 12 Emotionally Complex: 10 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 8 Weak Dialogue: 12 Tell-Don't-Show: 11 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 11 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13 Sentences Flow Naturally: 11 Overall Reader Engagement: 12 Overall Impression: 12
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 17.0, Believable Character Actions: 14.0, Nuanced Characters: 11.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 13.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 12.0, Elegant Prose: 10.0, Emotionally Engaging: 12.0, Emotionally Complex: 10.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 8.0, Weak Dialogue: 12.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 11.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12.0, Amateurish: 11.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5.0, Unearned Transformations: 6.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 11.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 12.0, Overall Impression: 12.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 73.4
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Gunpowder Rendezvous** The bar stinks of stale beer and gun oil. A ceiling fan spins lazily, barely stirring the haze of cigarette smoke. Spike Spiegel leans against the counter, a half-empty beer in one hand, a cigarette in the other. His good eye scans the room; the prosthetic one gives him a wider field but less depth. He’s here for a bounty: a lowlife named Viper, wanted for smuggling weapons. The reward is decent—enough to keep the Bebop fueled for a week. At the far end of the bar, a woman catches his attention. She’s wearing impossibly short shorts and a black crop top that shows off a dragon tattoo coiling down her right arm. Two modified Berettas rest in holsters on her thighs. She’s knocking back shots like water, but her eyes are sharp, scanning the room just like him. She glances over, catches his gaze, and holds it with a challenge. Spike smirks, stubs out his cigarette, and saunters over. “That’s a lot of firepower for such a small package,” he says, sliding onto the stool next to her. The woman snorts. “And you’re a tall drink of water with a death wish, coming over here.” She sizes him up. “Spike Spiegel, right? I’ve heard of you. Cowboy with a death wish.” “Guilty as charged. And you must be Revy—Two Hands. Your reputation precedes you.” She grins, all teeth. “What brings a space cowboy to this shithole?” “Same as you, I’d wager. Viper.” Revy’s grin fades. “Shit. I was hoping you were after someone else.” “Looks like we’re after the same rat. How about we team up? Split the reward down the middle.” Revy laughs. “Why the hell would I split with you? I can take Viper alone.” Spike shrugs. “Maybe. But his goons are everywhere. Could use someone to watch my back.” “Watch your back? I’d rather put a bullet in it.” “Charming.” Spike lights another cigarette. “Suit yourself. But if we both go after him separately, we might end up shooting each other by mistake. That’d be a waste.” Revy considers, then signals the bartender for two more shots. She slides one to Spike. “Fine. Temporary partnership. But I don’t trust you, and you don’t trust me. So we keep it professional.” Spike raises the shot. “To professional distrust.” They clink glasses and down the liquor. As if on cue, the door bursts open and three thugs stride in, scanning the room. One spots Spike and points. “That’s the guy! He’s been asking about Viper!” They draw their weapons. Spike sighs. “So much for subtlety.” Revy’s already on her feet, guns drawn. “Time to dance, cowboy.” The bar erupts in gunfire. Spike dives behind a table, drawing his Jericho and returning fire. Revy moves like a whirlwind, dual pistols blazing, dropping two men before they can blink. Spike takes out the third with a clean headshot. More thugs pour in from the back. Spike and Revy fight back-to-back, covering each other’s blind spots. Spike kicks a chair into one assailant, then disarms him with a swift judo throw. Revy’s bullets find their marks with lethal precision. In minutes, the floor is littered with bodies. Spike reloads. “Not bad, Two Hands.” Revy grins. “You’re not half bad yourself, spaceman.” They escape through a side door as sirens wail in the distance. Spike leads them to a rundown motel a few blocks away. They book a single room—cash only, no questions asked. Inside, it’s exactly what you’d expect: a sagging bed, flickering neon sign outside the window, and the smell of mildew. Revy flops onto the bed, pulling a flask from her hip. She takes a swig and offers it to Spike. He accepts, wincing at the burn. “So what’s the plan?” Revy asks. Spike sits on the edge of the bed, lighting a cigarette. “Viper’s holed up in a warehouse by the docks. We hit it at dawn, catch him sleeping.” Revy nods. “Sounds simple enough.” She studies him. “Why’d you leave the syndicate? Heard you were big time.” Spike’s expression darkens. “That’s a story for another day. Why’d you leave New York?” She scowls. “None of your damn business.” They fall into an uneasy silence, the tension thickening. Spike’s eyes linger on her tattoo, the curve of her waist. Revy notices and smirks. “See something you like?” “Maybe.” She sits up, leaning close. “You’re not my type, but I could make an exception.” Spike chuckles. “I’m everyone’s type.” They’re inches apart now. Revy’s breath smells of whiskey and danger. Spike reaches out, tucking a strand of hair behind her ear. She doesn’t pull away. Then, in a flash, Revy has a gun pressed to Spike’s temple. Spike’s own Jericho is aimed at her gut. They freeze, eyes locked. “Old habits die hard,” Revy says, her voice low. “Trust issues?” Spike asks, his finger on the trigger. “You could say that.” They hold the standoff for a long moment. Outside, a neon sign buzzes, casting red and blue shadows across their faces. Finally, Spike lowers his gun. Revy hesitates, then holsters hers. She leans back, breaking the tension. “Maybe we should get some sleep,” Spike suggests. “Dawn comes early.” Revy nods, but neither moves. The air still crackles with unspent energy. “Whatever happens, happens,” Spike murmurs, more to himself than to her. Revy laughs softly. “Yeah. I’m just here.” They lie down on opposite sides of the bed, backs to each other, guns within reach. Sleep doesn’t come easy, but they rest, knowing that tomorrow they’ll either be richer or dead. And maybe, just maybe, they’ll meet again.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This story successfully captures the essence of both characters and delivers on the prompt's requirements. The author demonstrates a solid understanding of Spike and Revy's personalities, incorporating key character traits like Spike's fatalistic attitude, prosthetic eye, and cigarette habit, alongside Revy's dual-wielding skills, foul mouth, and trust issues. The setting of a seedy bar transitioning to a motel room follows the requested structure effectively. The action sequences are well-executed, particularly the bar shootout that feels authentic to both characters' combat styles. The dialogue captures each character's voice reasonably well, with Revy's crude directness contrasting Spike's laid-back demeanor. The sexual tension builds naturally through their interactions, and the motel room standoff provides a satisfying climax that embodies their mutual attraction and distrust. However, the prose occasionally falls into workmanlike territory without achieving true elegance. Some descriptions feel perfunctory rather than evocative, and certain character interactions could benefit from more subtlety. The story hits its marks but doesn't transcend them, delivering competent fan fiction that fulfills expectations without surprising the reader. The ending maintains appropriate ambiguity, avoiding forced resolution while incorporating both characters' signature quotes naturally. The pacing moves efficiently through the required beats without feeling rushed, though some emotional beats could use deeper exploration. The story succeeds as an entertaining crossover that respects both source materials while delivering the requested elements of gunplay, drinking, and unresolved tension. Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 14.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 13.0, Elegant Prose: 12.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 13.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 6.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 8.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10.0, Amateurish: 8.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 14.0
+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 77.2
Prompt:
Folk Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Útiseta** The summer I turned fifteen, my father’s job dragged us from Stockholm to a speck of a village in northern Sweden. I hated everything about it—the endless forests, the silence, the way the mist clung to the fields even at noon. Then I met Astrid, and the midnight games began. Looking back, I know we were playing with fire. But at the time, it was just a thrill, a way to scare ourselves on those long, dark autumn nights. The game that changed everything was Útiseta. Astrid had learned it from her grandmother, who claimed to have the old knowledge. “It’s how the völvas spoke to the dead,” she told me, her blue eyes glinting in the lamplight of her bedroom. “We sit on a burial mound at midnight, face north, and press our palms to the earth. If we’re worthy, the spirits will give us knowledge.” She made it sound like a party trick, but there was an edge to her voice that made my skin prickle. We set out on a Friday night in late September. The air was knife‑cold, and a fat moon hung low, smudged by tendrils of fog. I wore two sweaters under my coat and still shivered as we crossed the empty field behind Astrid’s house. Our boots crunched on frozen grass. Somewhere in the distance, a dog barked, then fell silent. “There,” Astrid whispered, pointing. The mound rose ahead, a dark dome studded with moss‑covered stones. It was older than the village, older than the pines that ringed it. The locals avoided it, Astrid said, because they knew what slept beneath. I tried to laugh, but the sound died in my throat. We reached the base as my watch read 11:55. Astrid pulled a small knife from her pocket—a bone‑handled thing that looked ancient itself. “We need to leave an offering,” she said. “Hair or blood. The spirits want something personal.” I took a step back. “You never said anything about that.” “It’s important. Don’t worry, I’ll go first.” She grabbed a strand of her blonde braid, sawed it off, and knelt to tuck it into the soil. “Your turn.” My heart hammered. I wanted to refuse, but Astrid’s gaze held me. I’d come this far; backing out would make me a coward. I bent my head, felt the blade tug, then a snick as a lock of my dark hair came free. Astrid buried it beside hers. “Now we wait for midnight,” she said, checking her watch. The minutes crawled. The mist thickened, wrapping around us like a shroud. At exactly 12:00, we climbed to the top of the mound. The ground was damp and cold, seeping through my jeans as we sat cross‑legged, facing north as instructed. I placed my palms flat on the earth. The soil was icy, almost burning. “Close your eyes,” Astrid murmured. “Don’t speak. Just listen.” I did as I was told. At first, there was only the sound of our breathing and the distant hoot of an owl. Then, slowly, other noises crept in: the rustle of something moving through the underbrush, the creak of branches, the whisper of wind through grass. I felt the cold climb up my arms, a numbness that spread to my shoulders. A low hum seemed to rise from the ground, so faint I thought it might be my own blood rushing in my ears. But it grew, vibrating through my palms. I squeezed my eyes tighter, trying to focus. Then I heard it—a voice, or something like a voice, sighing my name: “Linnea…” It was barely audible, a breath on the wind. My eyes flew open. Astrid sat motionless, her eyes still closed, her face a mask of concentration. The mist had closed in, reducing the world to a grey sphere no more than ten feet across. I peered into the gloom, but nothing moved. “Astrid,” I whispered. “Did you hear that?” “Shh,” she hissed without opening her eyes. “Listen.” I swallowed hard and closed my eyes again. The humming intensified, now accompanied by a series of soft clicks, like pebbles shifting. The voice came again, clearer this time: “Linnea… help…” It was a child’s voice, thin and plaintive. I jerked my hands away. “Stop! I want to stop!” Astrid’s eyes snapped open. “What? What did you hear?” “A voice—a child, asking for help. Did you hear it?” She shook her head, but her face was pale. “I saw something. A vision, I think. It was Erik from school, but he was… different. Older, maybe, and there was blood—” A deep groan cut her off, rumbling up from the earth beneath us. The ground shuddered, and a sharp crack split the air, like ice breaking on a lake. We both screamed and scrambled to our feet, slipping and sliding down the slope. I didn’t look back until we reached the edge of the field, lungs burning. Astrid bent double, gasping. After a moment, she straightened and laughed—a high, nervous giggle. “Probably just a badger digging. Or a tree root snapping.” I nodded, but my hands wouldn’t stop shaking. “Yeah. Probably.” We walked home in silence, the mist thinning as we neared the village. At my doorstep, Astrid turned to me, her usual bravado back in place. “Same time next week? I’ve got another ritual—one that can make someone fall in love with you.” I forced a smile. “Sure.” But that night, lying in bed, I replayed every whisper, every tremor. Had we actually contacted something? Or had our own fear conjured it all? I couldn’t decide. What I did know was that after that night, the games grew darker. Astrid became obsessed, digging deeper into her grandmother’s old books, pushing us into rituals that felt less like play and more like summoning. And the line between reality and nightmare began to blur, until one night it vanished altogether. But that’s a story for another time.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt's requirements, successfully capturing the folk horror atmosphere of rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. The author effectively establishes Linnea as a reluctant Stockholm transplant and Astrid as the local guide into dangerous traditional practices. The Útiseta ritual is well-researched and authentically presented, mixing genuine Norse/Scandinavian elements with teenage experimentation. The narrative voice is consistent throughout, maintaining the first-person past tense recollection format while keeping the framing device appropriately transparent. The prose is generally clean and atmospheric, with effective imagery like "knife-cold air" and "mist wrapping around us like a shroud." The pacing builds tension steadily toward the midnight ritual. However, several elements feel somewhat predictable within the folk horror genre. The progression from hair offerings to supernatural manifestations follows familiar beats, and some descriptions lean toward conventional horror imagery. The characterization, while competent, doesn't achieve significant depth - Astrid remains somewhat archetypal as the dangerous local guide, and Linnea's internal conflict could be more nuanced. The ambiguity between supernatural and psychological explanations is maintained effectively, though the supernatural elements (voices, ground tremors) are fairly standard. The dialogue serves its purpose but lacks distinctive voice - the characters speak in a somewhat generic manner that doesn't strongly differentiate them or reveal deeper personality layers. The ending successfully sets up future escalation while maintaining the story's central tension. The writing avoids major technical flaws and maintains reader engagement throughout, though it doesn't transcend genre conventions to achieve exceptional originality or emotional complexity.
